race.name: PIRINEXUS 360
race.tagline: Trans-Pyrenean ultra-gravel through volcanic zones, medieval villages, and Costa Brava coast - Spain's answer to the 200-mile question

logistics.explanation: Girona is the cycling capital of Europe with excellent infrastructure. Barcelona El Prat (118 km) offers international flights; Girona airport closer but limited. Sea Otter Europe festival brings 68,000+ visitors creating accommodation pressure - one rider reports they 'couldn't sleep more than 4 hours the night before the race' due to festival atmosphere.

length.explanation: At 340 km with a 20-hour time limit, this pushes deep into ultra-distance territory. One rider described it as 'one the harder that we have done until now' after completing with an experienced brevet fanatic. Jordi Riera Valls covered the full distance in 13 hours 50 minutes, demonstrating the gap between elite and recreational pacing. Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands. As Sleep Deprivation puts it: "We only could sleep 4 hours the night before the race but we tried to be ready on time for start line and keep our mind aware for the first part of the ride."

technicality.explanation: Mixed terrain with 55% gravel proves challenging but manageable. Tom Owen rode it on 25c tires with a 1990s steel road bike, noting it 'proved anything but nimble; it felt practically lethal on rocky descents.' The final 49km features single-track sections ridden 'really fast' in darkness toward Girona. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds. As Tom Owen puts it: "I rode the Pirinexus, or my version of it, on a steel frame Decathlon road bike from the 1990s..."

elevation.explanation: The 3,400m of climbing centers on a brutal 50km section from Ceret to Col d'Ares. Riders report this stretch as 'really hard and a huge nightmare for a lot of participants' with 23km of gravel climbing. Many DNF at this point, though reaching the summit means 'you knew you could finish the race on time.' More climbing than SBT GRVL at the same score. As Timo Rokitta puts it: "On a gravel 'Via Verde' (a former railway converted into a cycle path) with many deep puddles and wet feet we climbed gently to our first destination, Olot."

climate.explanation: June 2019 riders enjoyed 'very pleasant temperatures, without too much heat' during the day. However, Tom Owen's early spring attempt saw water bottles and breakfast bananas freeze overnight. The night finish portion adds cold exposure risk after 12+ hours of exertion. Similar climate challenges to SBT GRVL. As Timo Rokitta puts it: "An ice-cold wind was blowing and the view was fantastic [at Col d'Ares]. On the very long descent it slowly got warmer and warmer."

altitude.explanation: Col d'Ares peaks at 1,513m with most of the route at lower elevations. The altitude itself poses minimal physiological challenge - the difficulty lies in the climbing effort rather than thin air. Start and finish at sea level in Girona with moderate mountain passes throughout. Modest altitude compared to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

adventure.explanation: The route crosses volcanic zones, Pyrenean passes, medieval villages, and Costa Brava coastline in a single push. Riders describe crossing diverse terrain types within the time limit, from gravel climbs through French borders to coastal approaches. The night finish through single-track creates a memorable conclusion to an epic journey.

prestige.explanation: Part of UCI Gravel World Series and integrated with Sea Otter Europe festival. Seven editions have established its reputation among European ultra-endurance cyclists. The event attracts 'cyclists from various areas of Europe' and provides exclusive Bioracer jerseys designed specifically for the challenge.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized with Shimano mechanical support throughout the route and multiple aid stations. Sea Otter Europe backing provides professional race infrastructure. Two basic provisioning points serve the non-stop format, though riders can arrange personal support teams for the extended challenge.

experience.explanation: Riders finish 'tired but happy and excited' after conquering Col d'Ares - the mental milestone that determines completion. The night riding finale through single-track toward Girona creates shared suffering and accomplishment. Participants consistently highlight 'the toughness of the course' while demonstrating it's achievable with proper training.

community.explanation: Growing European participation with Friday evening race number pickup and exclusive jersey distribution creating pre-race atmosphere. Elite riders like Tom Owen and competitive cyclists like Jordi Riera Valls participate alongside recreational cyclists. Field sizes of 50-96 riders mentioned across different editions.

field_depth.explanation: Attracts experienced ultra-endurance cyclists from across Europe, but not major series or major pro field depth. Strong regional competition with international participants. Personal challenge format means less emphasis on elite racing. Similar competitive depth to Rule of Three. As Tom Owen's Bikepacking Trip puts it: "My water bottles froze both nights. On the first night my breakfast banana also froze."

value.explanation: Entry includes Sea Otter Europe festival access, aid stations, Shimano mechanical support, and exclusive race jerseys. The 20-hour supported challenge with professional infrastructure provides reasonable value for European ultra-distance events. Festival integration adds expo access and post-race services.

expenses.explanation: Girona offers reasonable European pricing. Budget flights to Barcelona or Girona from European hubs. Accommodation varies but available. No extreme remoteness premium. Total trip cost moderate by European standards - estimated $500-800 including travel from within Europe. More affordable than Crusher in the Tushar.

distances.name: Pirinexus 360
distances.description: Full ultra-distance loop crossing Spain-France border via Col d'Ares

distances.name: Half Pirinexus
distances.description: Shorter challenge option with reduced climbing

history.origin_story: Created after Jordi Cantal completed the 340km Pirinexus route alone in 18 hours during summer 2014. What began as a personal challenge evolved into an organized event that has become 'one of the most authentic, beautiful, tough and prestigious gravel races in Europe.'

series_affiliation: Gran Fondo World Tour Gravel Series
key_features: La Garrotxa Volcanic Zone with 40 volcanic cones

weather.notes: One of the best cycling months in Girona. Night riding portion cooler. Summit weather unpredictable.

nearest_airports.name: Barcelona El Prat
nearest_airports.notes: Major hub, bus to Girona ~20 EUR

logistics.accommodation_notes: Book early - Sea Otter Europe brings 68,000+ visitors
logistics.bike_services: Girona is cycling capital of Europe - excellent shops, rentals, transfers
logistics.camping:
Camping Intel

> "There's no lack of camping sites in this corner of Spain, and Catalonia is one of the few regions in Spain whe

gear_recommendations.lights: 1000+ lumens front, rear light, spare batteries
gear_recommendations.clothing: Layers for 10-26C range, rain jacket mandatory
gear_recommendations.navigation: GPS with GPX, backup phone, route book

dnf_factors: Col d'Ares historically main DNF point

final_verdict.one_liner: The thinking rider's 340k—half the distance of the big ultras but twice as beautiful, with a border-crossing climb that sends half the field home early.
final_verdict.should_you_race: You need 200+ mile legs and 40mm+ tires minimum—the technical border descent after Col d'Ares will put narrower rubber on foot. This isn't a watts contest; it's navigation, bike handling, and knowing when to push through the Pyrenean climbs versus when to survive them. Show up undertrained and that 18-hour cutoff becomes very real very fast.
final_verdict.alternatives: Gravel Worlds in Nebraska gives you similar distance with half the climbing and none of the charm. Dirty Kanza (Unbound) trades European scenery for American suffer-fest purity, while Eroica keeps the Old World vibe but loses the modern challenge.

course_description.character: The Pirinexus is half smooth greenway cruise, half bike-destroying nightmare. You'll roll 55 kilometers on the silky Via Verde del Carrilet thinking this is easy, then spend the next 70 kilometers climbing volcanic hills and technical gravel that'll have you questioning your tire choice. The route crosses into France where the road literally disappears into rocky descents that punish anything under 40mm tires.

suffering_zones.label: La Garrotxa Volcanic Reckoning
suffering_zones.desc: The greenway party ends and reality hits. Seventy kilometers through volcanic terrain with 900 meters of climbing, starting with Coll de Coubet—a 9km grind that gives no respite.

suffering_zones.label: Col d'Ares Death March
suffering_zones.desc: The 17.9km border crossing at 1,513 meters where dreams die. This is where most DNFs happen and the mental breaking point that separates finishers from the field.

suffering_zones.label: French Descent Carnage
suffering_zones.desc: After grinding to the border, the road disappears into technical rocky descents. Riders on narrow tires walk while suspension bikes roll past laughing.

suffering_zones.label: Costa Brava False Hope
suffering_zones.desc: The coast looks like relief but delivers rolling agricultural roads and hidden climbs. Your legs are already cooked and there's still 50 miles of punishment ahead.

course_description.signature_challenge: Col d'Ares is the course executioner—a 17.9-kilometer climb to the French border that peaks at 1,513 meters. It's not just the elevation; it's arriving there after 80 miles of volcanic punishment, knowing that technical descents await on the other side. Most riders call it quits here, and the ones who don't spend the descent walking their bikes down rocky trails that shouldn't exist on a cycling route.

unsplash_photos.description: a river running through a city next to tall buildings
a river running through a city next to tall buildings

primary.name: Maxxis Reaver
primary.why: Technical all-rounder. EXO+ casing shrugs off rocks and roots.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

terrain.surface: 55% gravel/dirt, 45% asphalt. Via Verde greenway sections, volcanic terrain, singletrack descents.
terrain.primary: Mixed gravel and asphalt with volcanic zones and technical border descent

videos.title: Teaser Canyon Pirinexus Challenge 2021
videos.description:
The CANYON PIRINEXUS CHALLENGE is currently a personal non-stop challenge of 340km. Participants will have until midnight to complete a route that takes in all types of terrain. All bikes are allowed, although probably the most appropriate are the gravel or the cyclo-cross bikes. Road bikes with 28 (or 25) tyres and mountain bikes 29’ wheels with slicks.

Participants will leave the sea and head inland into the regions of Girona following the course of the Ter river up to the Colomers dam. Once there, the course will turn left towards Les Gavarres mountains. It will then mainly run along the crest of the mountain in an easterly direction, enjoying views of the El Gironès and L’Empordà regions whilst surrounded by cork oaks. All the tracks are in very good condition and have low technical difficulty.

videos.curation_reason: Most recent first-person race experience showing the actual route from Palafrugell to La Canya on gravel bike.

videos.description: On September 26th we will live an incredible adventure!
